bestBHT.bht: In Him, God was pleased to have all the fulness dwell, which is the foundation of reconciliation. This grand climax statement affirms the deity of Christ and the presence of all divine attributes in Him. He possesses abundant wisdom, power, and grace to redeem and save us. In every situation and task, the Church finds no deficiency in Him, as He is always ready to equip her. Through Christ, all grace comes, all communion with Him is made possible, and He is the head of the Church, full of grace and truth.

Henry Alford: Because in Him He was pleased...that the whole fulness should dwell."
The various other interpretations see in my Greek Test."
This indwelling is the foundation of the reconciliation.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: in him—that is, in the Son (Matthew 3:17).
all fulness—rather as Greek, 'all the fulness,' namely, of God, whatever divine excellence is in God the Father (Colossians 2:9, Ephesians 3:19; compare John 1:16, John 3:34).
Albert Barnes: He chose to confer on his Son such a rank, that in all things he might have the pre-eminence, and that there might be in him 'all fulness.'
We have a Saviour who is in no respect deficient in wisdom, power, and grace to redeem and save us.

In no situation of trouble and danger will the church find that there is a deficiency in him; in no enterprise to which she can put her hands will there be a lack of power in her great Head to enable her to accomplish what he calls her to.
Marvin Vincent: God was well pleased that in Him, etc.
In Christ dwelt all the fullness of God as deity.
Thus the phrase in Him should all the fullness dwell gathers into a grand climax the previous statements.
John Calvin: This has been in accordance with the counsel of God, that all fullness may dwell in him."
Christ is all things to us: apart from him we have nothing."
All that detract from Christ, or that impair his excellence, or rob him of his offices, or, in fine, take away a drop from his fullness, overturn, so far as is in their power, God’s eternal counsel.
Philip Schaff: This fulness of 'habitual grace' (as the scholastic theologians term it) shows the certainty of the fulfilment of the Divine purpose: ‘that in all things He might have the preeminence’ (Colossians 1:18)."
The fact that it did thus dwell in the Incarnate Word is that on which the salvation of the Church rests.
But the fact that it did thus dwell in the Incarnate Word is that on which the salvation of the Church rests.
Archibald T. Robertson: A recognized technical term in theology, denoting the totality of the Divine powers and attributes" (Lightfoot).
Paul gathers them all up in Christ, a full and flat statement of the deity of Christ.
All the divine attributes are at home in Christ.
John Gill: There is a fulness of nature in Christ; the light of nature is from him, and communicated by him to mankind; the blessings of nature are the blessings of his left hand, which he distributes to his people as he thinks fit; and all things in nature are subservient to his mediatorial kingdom and glory.

There is a fulness of grace in him, out of which saints receive, and grace for grace, or a large abundance of it; the fulness of the spirit of grace, and of all the graces and gifts of the Spirit is in him.

It is his good will and sovereign pleasure, that all grace should come through Christ, all communion with him here, and all enjoyment of him hereafter; which greatly enhances and sets forth the glory of Christ as Mediator, one considerable branch of which is, that he is full of grace and truth; this qualifies him to be the head of the church.
John Wesley: For it pleased the Father that all fulness — All the fulness of God.
Should dwell in him — Constantly, as in a temple; and always ready for our approach to him.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Him, God was pleased to have all the fulness dwell. This indwelling is the foundation of the reconciliation in Christ. The phrase in Him should all the fullness dwell emphasizes the grand climax of the previous statements and asserts the deity of Christ. In Christ, all the divine attributes are present and at home. He possesses wisdom, power, and grace in abundance to redeem and save us. There is no deficiency in Him, and He is always ready to equip the Church for every situation and task. It is through Christ that all grace comes, and all communion and enjoyment of Him are made possible. He is the head of the Church, full of grace and truth. The Father's pleasure and will are fulfilled in Christ, as He is the dwelling place of the fulness of God.

In Him, God was pleased to have all the fulness dwell, which is the foundation of reconciliation. This grand climax statement affirms the deity of Christ and the presence of all divine attributes in Him. He possesses abundant wisdom, power, and grace to redeem and save us. In every situation and task, the Church finds no deficiency in Him, as He is always ready to equip her. Through Christ, all grace comes, all communion with Him is made possible, and He is the head of the Church, full of grace and truth.

In Christ, God was pleased to have all the fulness dwell, establishing the foundation of reconciliation. This grand climax statement confirms the deity of Christ and the presence of divine attributes in Him. His abundant wisdom, power, and grace enable Him to redeem and save us. The Church finds no deficiency in Him, as He equips her for every situation. Through Christ, all grace flows, and communion with Him is made possible. As the head of the Church, He is full of grace and truth, fulfilling the Father's will.

In Christ, all the fullness of God dwells, establishing the foundation of reconciliation. This statement confirms the deity of Christ and the presence of divine attributes in Him. He possesses abundant wisdom, power, and grace to redeem and save us. The Church finds no deficiency in Him, as He equips her for every situation. Through Christ, all grace comes, and communion with Him is made possible. As the head of the Church, He is full of grace and truth, fulfilling the Father's will.

In Christ, all the fullness of God dwells, revealing His deity and the abundance of divine attributes. Through Him, the foundation of reconciliation is established. Christ possesses limitless wisdom, power, and grace to redeem and save. The Church finds no lack in Him, as He equips her for every situation. In Him, all grace flows, facilitating communion and enjoyment. As the head of the Church, Christ is full of grace and truth, fulfilling the Father's will with His dwelling of the fullness of God within Him.
